module.title: Web Accessibility (a11y)
module.description: Build inclusive web applications that work for everyone

lessons.title: Why Accessibility Matters
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- 15% of world's population has some form of disability.
- Accessibility (a11y) = making web usable by everyone.
- Legal requirement in many countries (ADA, WCAG).
- Benefits everyone: better UX, SEO, mobile support.

---

# Accessibility: Building for Everyone

## The Reality

**1 billion people** worldwide live with disabilities. That's 15% of the global population.

**Types of disabilities:**
- **Visual**: Blindness, low vision, color blindness
- **Auditory**: Deafness, hard of hearing
- **Motor**: Can't use mouse, limited fine motor control
- **Cognitive**: Learning disabilities, memory issues, ADHD

## Real-World Impact

### Scenario 1: Keyboard Navigation
```
User with broken arm can't use mouse.
Your website: All buttons require mouse clicks
Result: User can't complete purchase
```

### Scenario 2: Screen Reader
```
Blind user wants to buy train ticket.
Your website: Images without alt text, forms without labels
Result: User can't determine ticket options
```

### Scenario 3: Color Contrast
```
User with low vision (40+ years old)
Your website: Light gray text on white background
Result: User strains to read, leaves frustrated
```

## Why Accessibility Matters

### 1. It's the Right Thing
The web should be accessible to everyone, regardless of ability.

### 2. Legal Requirements
- **USA**: ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act)
- **EU**: European Accessibility Act
- **Canada**: Accessible Canada Act

Companies sued for inaccessible websites:
- Domino's Pizza
- Target
- Netflix
- Harvard and MIT

### 3. Business Benefits

**Larger market:**
- $13 trillion annual disposable income of people with disabilities globally

**Better SEO:**
- Semantic HTML helps search engines understand content
- Alt text improves image search

**Improved UX for everyone:**
- Captions help in loud environments
- Keyboard navigation helps power users
- High contrast helps in bright sunlight

### 4. Technical Benefits

- **Cleaner code**: Semantic HTML is easier to maintain
- **Better testing**: Automated a11y testing catches bugs
- **Future-proof**: Accessible sites work better on new devices

## Common Misconceptions

❌ **"Accessibility is only for blind users"**
✅ Benefits all disabilities AND situational limitations

❌ **"It's too expensive and time-consuming"**
✅ Cheaper to build in from the start than retrofit later

❌ **"It makes websites ugly"**
✅ Accessible design can be beautiful (Apple, Google, Microsoft)

❌ **"Only government sites need to be accessible"**
✅ All websites should be accessible

## The POUR Principles

WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) uses POUR:

**Perceivable**: Users can perceive the information
**Operable**: Users can operate the interface
**Understandable**: Users can understand the content
**Robust**: Works with assistive technologies

lessons.title: Keyboard Navigation
Screen Reader Support
lessons.content:
# Essential to know - Screen readers convert visual UI to audio/speech. - Alt text describes images for blind users. - ARIA labels provide context when visible text isn't enough. - Form labels must be associated with inputs. - Dynamic content needs live regions for announcements. --- # Screen Reader Support: Making the Invisible Audible ## How Screen Readers Work Screen readers (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver): 1. Parse HTML DOM 2. Convert to audio/speech 3. Allow keyboard navigation 4. Announce dynamic changes **Example experience:** ``` User presses Tab... Screen reader: "Search, edit text, blank" User types "shoes"... Screen reader: "S... H... O... E... S... shoes" User presses Tab... Screen reader: "Search button" ``` ## Images and Alt Text ### Informative Images ```jsx // ✅ Descriptive alt text // ✅ For complex images, use longdesc or describe in text

[Detailed text description of the diagram]

``` ### Decorative Images ```jsx // ❌ Screen reader: "Image, decorative border" (annoying!) // ✅ Empty alt hides from screen readers // ✅ Even better - use CSS for decorative elements
``` ### Functional Images ```jsx // Icon buttons need descriptive labels // ❌ Screen reader: "Button" // ✅ Screen reader: "Delete item, button" // ✅ Or use visible text ``` ## Form Labels ### Explicit Labels (Preferred) ```jsx // ✅ Using htmlFor (id reference) // Screen reader: "Email Address, edit text, blank" ``` ### Implicit Labels ```jsx // ✅ Wrapping input ``` ### When Visible Label Isn't Enough ```jsx

Search products by name, category, or SKU.

// Screen reader: "Search, edit text, Search products by name..." ``` ## ARIA Labels and Descriptions ### aria-label ```jsx // When there's no visible text // Screen reader: "Close dialog, button" (not "Times button") ``` ### aria-labelledby ```jsx // Reference another element for label

Shipping Address

...
``` ### aria-describedby ```jsx // Additional context Must be at least 8 characters with numbers and symbols. ``` ## Live Regions Announce dynamic changes to screen readers: ```jsx function SearchResults() { const [results, setResults] = useState([]); const [isSearching, setIsSearching] = useState(false); return (
{/* Live region for announcements */}
{isSearching && 'Searching...'} {!isSearching && results.length > 0 && `${results.length} results found`} {!isSearching && results.length === 0 && 'No results found'}
{/* Visual results */}
    {results.map(result => (
  • {result.title}
    • ))}
); } // Screen reader announces: "5 results found" when search completes ``` ## Testing with Screen Readers **Free screen readers:** - **NVDA** (Windows) - Free, most popular - **VoiceOver** (Mac/iOS) - Built-in (Cmd+F5) - **TalkBack** (Android) - Built-in **Testing checklist:** - Can you navigate the entire page? - Are images described meaningfully? - Do form inputs have labels? - Are dynamic changes announced? - Is the reading order logical?

questions.question:
What's wrong with this code?
Submit
options: Divs aren't keyboard accessible - should use button
questions.explanation: Divs are not focusable or keyboard accessible. Use semantic <button> for clickable actions.

questions.question: Which heading structure is correct?
options: h1 → h3 → h2 (skipping and out of order)
questions.explanation: Headings should follow logical hierarchy (h1 → h2 → h3) without skipping levels.

questions.question: Which image alt text is best?
options: alt="John presenting Q3 sales data showing 25% growth"
questions.explanation: Alt text should be descriptive and convey the purpose/content of the image.

questions.question: Which key activates a button?
questions.explanation: Buttons are activated with Enter or Space keys. Tab just moves focus.

questions.question: Why shouldn't you use positive tabIndex values?
options: They break the logical tab order
questions.explanation: Positive tabIndex values override natural tab order and can create confusing navigation.

questions.question:
What should you remove?
*:focus { outline: none; }
options: It's fine if you add a replacement focus style
Remove it - focus indicators are required
Only remove it for mouse users
questions.explanation: Removing focus indicators makes keyboard navigation impossible. Always show where focus is.

questions.question: When should alt text be empty (alt="")?
options: When the image is decorative only
questions.explanation: Empty alt text hides decorative images from screen readers. They don't announce "image" for these.

questions.question: What does aria-label do?
options: Provides accessible name when no visible text exists
questions.explanation: aria-label provides an accessible name for elements when visible text isn't available (like icon buttons).

questions.question: Which attribute associates a label with an input?
questions.explanation: The htmlFor attribute on label matches the id on input to programmatically associate them.
